There were some technological issues when the Hispano cannon was converted to belt feed. Among them was the fact that the chamber width was 1/16 inch too large, which allowed backflow gases to enter the barrel and jam the breechlock. Reducing the size of the chamber width helped solve the problem and lessened the amount of weapon failures.

The 1943 modification of the Hispano Mk. II saw the replacement of graphite lubricant with fluid lubrication. This increased the gun's reliability beyond that of the 1942 modification of the Hispano Mk. II.

Replacing the turrets' %s mm machine guns' worn barrels and striking mechanism increases the fire density and decreases the chance of the gun jamming from overheating.

Installation of a rangefinder allows for the more accurate determination of the range to a target.

Installation of a laser rangefinder allows for the more accurate determination of the range to and required ballistics for a target. Installation of a laser warning system allows for the detection of laser-guided munitions and laser rangefinders being targeted at the vehicle.

Installation of the 1G46 laser rangefinder in conjunction with the 1V528-1 ballistic calculator allows for the calculating of the range to and required ballistics for a target. Installation of the TShU-1 rough laser sensors and TShU-1-11 precision laser sensors allows for the detection of laser-guided munitions and laser rangefinders targeted at the tank.

Proper maintencance and, if necessary, replacement of the engines improves their performance.
Replacement of the propellers with new ones increases the vessel's performance
Cleaning the vessel's hull of marine life decreases drag and improves hydrodynamics, increasing the vessel's maximum speed.
Proper maintenance and, if necessary, replacement of the vessel's rudder improves its agility.
Improved and replenished repair equiment allows for the more rapid and effective repair of damage while at sea.
Improved and replenished fire extinguishers allows for the more rapid and effective extinguishing of fires.

Injecting titanium tetrachloride (TiCl₄), silicon tetrachloride (SiCl₄), chlorosulfuric acid (HSO₃Cl), or hexachloroethane ((CCl₃)₂) into the engine manifold or boilers produces a white smoke that lies low on the water's surface.
Proper maintencance and, if necessary, replacement of the bilge pumps allows for increased capacity, allowing for more rapid pumping of water.
Consistent rangefinder alignment allows for increased accuracy in the measurement of distance to a target.
Consistent lubrication of the traverse mechanism for the vessel's primary armament increases its rotation speed.
Consistent lubrication of the traverse mechanism for the vessel's auxiliary armament increases its rotation speed.
Consistent lubrication of the traverse mechanism for the vessel's anti-aircraft armament increases its rotation speed.
Added sandbags and gun shields create additional protection against fire and shrapnel damage.
The addition of an anti-shrapnel lining provides extra protection for the crew and modules against shrapnel.
Proper maintencance and, if necessary, replacement of the gun liner increases the gun's accuracy and reduces its fire spread.
Calling in artillery support launches a spread of artillery shells at the targeted point.
A decrease in the maximum speed of the torpedo increases its range.
Equipping depth charges allows for their deployment to damage nearby small vessels and submarines.
Proper maintencance and, if necessary, replacement of the ventination system ensures consistent, clean air-flow, reducing the risk of the crew inhaling smoke during a fire.
The storage of ammunition in wet racks reduces the risk of fire and ammunition detonation in the event of a hit to the ammunition racks.
The installation of a rocket launcher allows the vessel to fire rockets or rocket-propelled bombs while at sea.
The carrying of naval mines allows for their deployment while at sea.
